reviewText:
I was two steps from winning and the computer surprised me with a one move win on hard!  Great Job!

This is a great game.  As a big fan of Go (igo, Baduk, etc.) this has a good number of qualities of the go game.  First, its rules are simple. Movement of pieces is very simple and can be understood very quickly.  The format of the game is quite logical and without reading the rules, it only took one or two games to understand all the movement and basic strategy of the game. Second, it has some depth to the game play.  It is not so simple to have standard moves (at least not for me yet), though it may at some point for me in the future.  The good thing is that there is a bit of repeatibility in play because of the different setups for the board.
I have played on all three board types and I can now definitely say that this game has a good future.  The other board types are quite challenging compared to the first, and the strategy definitely has to change for each board type.  That makes it a bit more interesting since there may be even more unique ways to play in the future.

I am quite happy with this game. It mixes the qualities of Chess with go by adopting the simplicity of go, but the faster pace of chess and removal of pieces off the board.  With the rating system, I am also looking forward to playing online at some point.

I should also note, having now played the game a bit and beaten the computer AI on Hard level, the pace is not too slow.  Many times when you get into the harder levels, the AI slows considerably.  One of the things I like about this game is that it has a relatively quick pace (can finish a game within 20 minutes easily), and it still maintains some interesting depth.  I assume the elite and impossible levels will get even slower, though.  It is good to maintain a reasonable pace, and I hope the advanced AI games can still finish within an hour.

Once I play some online games, I will again, update this review.

reviewText: The core game of Khet is amazing. If you like chess and other strategy board games, you will most certainly like Khet. Unfortunately, this digital version of the game leaves a lot to be desired. The game is very buggy, and crashed multiple times when I was trying to play an online game with a friend. Good news is, that my friend submitted error logs to the developer and he fixed most problems within a day. But there are still some lagging issues. For one, the game will always crash if you have a browser window open that is playing video such as Netflix or Amazon Video. Also, the interface is not very good. Almost every digital version of chess that's ever been released has allowed players to scroll through all the moves made in the game. This is incredibly useful when you are playing an asyncronous game, and you need to refresh your memory on what the last several moves were. This is a feature that is sorely needed in Khet. Even if you are playing a live game and you happen to look away from the screen for a second while your opponent moves, it can be extrememly difficult to try and figure out where he just moved, and there's no way to click back and see. Overall though, I do recommend this game, simply because Khet is such a deep and interesting game. And hopefully in the future, the interface can be fixed with an update. As of January 2016, I would give this game a 6/10. With some interface tweaks and bug fixes, this game would easily be a 10/10.

reviewText:
A very good concept and quick to understand too.
The AI is rather simple right now, but the Devs are increasing the AI's level with each patch.
Game works very well without any problems (So far ;-) )

The concept is to take out the opposing Pharaoh with your laser. To do this you bounce the beam from your Sphinx in your right hand corner into their Pharaoh. There are pyramids with 1 side mirrors, Scarabs with double-sided mirrors and Anubis 'Blockers' that can block the laser, but only from the front. You can remove pyramids by hitting a non-mirrored side with the laser, and Anubis can be removed by hitting the sides or back.
Each turn you can move one piece, one square OR rotate one piece by 90 degrees.

That is pretty much it for the rules! Quite simple in concept, but can be tricky when facing a real opponent!

A very well made version of the Board game, without pointless visuals or silliness that could slow down or spoil the game itself.

I would thoroughly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys games of logic, strategy and tactics.

reviewText:
Starting off as a class project from Tulane University in 2004, Khet has its roots buried in academia and education, and boasts an award from MENSA select on its store page and website. Khet 2.0 is a thinking mans strategic board game and plays very similar to Laser Chess, but also has elements akin to the 3000 year old game Go. The concept of Khet is somewhat similar to chess: destroy your enemy's Pharaoh with your Sphinx Laser via positioning and strategy, while protecting your own as he does the same.

The simple principles make for just as much memorization, logic and planning as Chess, but they reduce the emphasis on knowing moves, and as a result tend to make on-the-fly strategy a bit more open and accessible. Overall, Khet was perfect for me because as much as I love battling wits in Chess, I rarely have the time or patience for it and Khet 2.0 offers much faster games for those looking for them, but also offers support for asynchronous play, so I'm never hurried or rushed to make a move when I want to take my time or play casually.

Highlights
The gameplay and fun of Khet comes down to pitting wits against friends, opponents or AI and approaching a win while mavourering an attack and simultaneously paying attention to defense and if you like the idea of an arguably simpler chess, it's an easy sell. What really matters for Khet 2.0 is the development team and how well they bring the concept to Steam. While there are technical issues and small problems with the title, the Development team are pretty committed and regularly post updates, bugfixes and more and despite flaws, the multiplayer platform is overall solid and works well.

* Asynchronous multiplayer support is a great feature and lets casual players like myself start a few games, play a move against different players and then forget about it for a day or two and only come back to those games when I need to. It also helps to reduce the problems associated with lower numbers of players in multiplayer.
* The choice of cross platform and non-DRM-restricted servers deserve special mention. They mean multiplayer is universal and should the game ever be made on other platforms, everyone would be able to integrate.
* Local multiplayer is also included and a pass-and-play mode for two people playing on the same computer (i.e. controllers or two keyboards, etc).

Mistakes and Annoyances
Khet 2.0 is a fairly simple concept, design and overall game which makes it ripe for improvement and addition over time. Unfortunately it's still slightly rough around the edges and has some minor issues that could affect your choice of a purchase.

The multiplayer functionality works, but it's somewhat lacking in depth, and the number of players online is a concern for a game like this. Matches are listed by tags showing the settings of the game, but there are no filter options whatsoever. I spent some time in the lobby and was only ever able to see the same 20 or so games already in progress, and with no spectator option, this was essentially pointless data to show. Similarly, chatting in game is impossible, and communicating via Steam is the only current option, which pauses gameplay and causes frustration.

An Eye of Horus Beam Splitter game piece was originally launched as an expansion piece for the board game and has been added as a DLC. While it does significantly affect gameplay, and is priced fairly, it's still hard to view this as anything other than a cash grab. Considering the price  of the original title and the presumably small amount of development time this took to add, it should be included in the original title instead of offered as DLC. The big block of DLC promotion on the title screen is also rather jarring.

* The graphics are fairly boring, bland and poor. While it doesn't affect gameplay and isn't a reason not to buy, it would've been nice to had some colour customization, themes, designs, backgrounds or anything to add to the very bland art design.
* The A.I. is somewhat unpredictable, which adds an element of chance, but also makes beating the A.I. very easy in many situations, even on extreme difficulties.

Recommendations
At the time of review, Khet 2.0 is available on Steam for ¬£6.99/9.99‚Ç¨/$9.99 which, if you enjoy chess and are likely to put more than 10-15 hours into this title, is well worth the price. When weighed against competition however, it may feel a little overpriced. Hero Academy, for comparison, is a similarly simple asynchronous strategic board game and comes in at half the price, and Tabletop Simulator, a game with multiple gameplay elements, including Chess, Go, and tons more, is only around twice the price.

When on sale however, Khet 2.0 is a good deal for the strategic thinking lover. There's also a 2-Pack option which saves you a few extra bucks if you have a friend.

The Eye of Horus DLC includes the Beam Splitter piece originally offered as an expansion piece to Khet 1.0. It significantly affects gameplay and you can try it out in multiplayer games by finding someone hosting a game with it included (only the host needs have the DLC to use it). That said, it's, at least in my opinion, a bad move not to include this in the base game, so each to their own.

* Hive is an equally unique and interesting take on a strategic board game which comes from the same team under the same academic roots and is worth a look for anyone who liked Khet 2.0

- The graphics aren't great, I don't mind and neither should you because you don't play this kind of game for AAA graphics but for the experience. Still, it would, in my opinion, be an improvement if the graphics were better because it pleases the eye.
- The AI on EASY mode is way too easy, play it only to get started. But also on MEDIUM, the AI seems to be an idiot. Yesterday, I won on HARD and had the feeling that the AI should have seen it coming. Maybe EXPERT or IMPOSSIBLE will give me the difficulty I need, but I can't tell yet. Anyway, there is a multiplayer option if you want the real stuff.

Short: this game is ok, but it needs bugfixes. I will change this review when those bugfixes have released.
